description: Let sigma_m(n) be result of applying the sum-of-divisors function m times to n; call n (m,k)-perfect if sigma_m(n) = k*n; sequence gives log_2 of the (2,2)-perfect numbers.
comments: Cohen and te Riele prove that any even (2,2)-perfect number (a "superperfect" number) must be of the form 2^(p-1) with 2^p-1 prime (Suryanarayana) and the converse also holds. Any odd superperfect number must be a perfect square (Kanold). Searches up to >10^20 did not find any odd examples. - _Ralf Stephan_, Jan 16 2003See also the Cohen-te Reile links under A019276.
references: Graeme L. Cohen and Herman J. J. te Riele, Iterating the sum-of-divisors function, Experimental Mathematics, 5 (1996), pp. 93-100.
links: G. L. Cohen & H. J. J. te Riele, Iterating the Sum-of-Divisors Function
formula: Coincides with A000043(n) - 1 unless odd superperfect numbers exist.
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
extensions: 2 more terms sent by _Jud McCranie_, Jun 01 2000
